Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Quantifying the tempo of genome theft in polyploid, female-only Ambystoma salamanders
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will test a hypothesis to explain how a lineage of female-only salamanders has been able to persist for millions of years. Most animals reproduce sexually even though there is a high evolutionary cost of making males. Males compete with females for resources and decrease the genetic resemblance between a female and her offspring. Few animal species reproduce without mating and most only live for a short evolutionary time. However, an all-female lineage of salamanders (the oldest known all-female vertebrate in North American) has been able to persist for approximately 6 million years. Because the persistence of asexual animals is rare, they can provide valuable clues about the costs and benefits of sexual reproduction. Sometimes these female-only salamanders are able to obtain new genetic material from males of closely related species. Thus, they may gain the benefits of both sexual and asexual reproduction. To test this idea, the researchers will measure the importance of genetic contributions from sexual species into the all-female asexual species over evolutionary time. In addition, the project will include the training of undergraduate and graduate students and outreach activities such as museum displays and social blogs.

This research will quantify the rate and evolutionary history of genome leakage from sexual species in to the unisexual Ambystoma lineage, which will allow us to test the hypothesis that recurrent genome contribution accounts for the greater lineage age of unisexual Ambystoma as compared to other gynogenetic taxa. The researchers will use genome-scale data and evolutionary demographic modeling to evaluate multiple evolutionary scenarios ranging from no genetic contributions from sexual species, to recent (but limited) genome contributions only, or ongoing genome contributions. This will be accomplished by using custom bioinformatics tools to sort genetic variation among the multiple genomes of unisexual salamanders, comparing this variation to that of the genomes of sexual species thought to be the source of novel genetic variation in unisexuals and then using statistical genetic models to estimate the magnitude and timing of genetic exchange between unisexual and sexual salamanders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Among animals, sexual reproduction is overwhelmingly the most common way that individuals pass their genetic material to their offspring yet the evolution of sexual reproduction is still mysterious. For example, why don’t animals make offspring using the speed and efficiency of cloning, similar to the way that bacteria and some plants reproduce?

In fact, there are multiple groups of all-female animals that surprisingly reproduce without sex or with little input from males. To understand the evolution of sexual reproduction, these outliers provide necessary comparisons to sexual groups. However, it is still difficult to determine if all-female groups periodically engage in difficult to detect sexual reproduction.

This research quantified the history of sexual and asexual reproduction in a unique group of non-sexual vertebrates, all-female mole salamanders (genus Ambystoma). All-female salamanders primarily reproduce clonally, but occasionally acquire sperm from males of other species. Together, these reproductive strategies may give all-female salamanders the advantages of both ways of reproducing. This project developed new genomic resources to trace the evolutionary history of their genomes beyond the formation of the all-female group approximately five million years ago. A particularly important result is that the “theft” of sperm from different sexual species has proceeded at different time frames, where the genetic material of one salamander species has moved into the all-female lineage more recently than a different species.

These results have provided important insights for how all-female salamanders have engaged in sexual reproduction over millions of years while still remaining an independent all-female lineage. This information verifies that all-female salamanders have taken genomes from sexual species for long periods of time and allows for future comparisons using the methods developed in this project to focus on specific all-female populations that have interacted with sexual species for shorter or longer periods.

In addition, the researchers collaborated with scientific illustrators to create an animated video and graphics to describe the surprising diversity of reproduction among animals (available at: http://rddenton.com/index.php/animal-reproductive-diversity/). This product is freely available to educators and researchers to provide charismatic visual information to illustrate an often confusing aspect of evolutionary biology.
